TASMANIAN: A small grumpy animal found only in Tasmania
TEACHER: A person who helps students learn at school
TENNIS: A game played with rackets and a small ball
TENT: A portable shelter used for sleeping outdoors
TERMITE: A small insect that eats wood and lives in mounds
THIRSTY: Feeling like you need to drink something
THRONE: A special chair for a king or queen to sit on
THUNDER: The loud booming sound you hear after a flash of lightning
TIE: A narrow piece of cloth worn around the neck with a shirt
TIGER: A large wild cat with orange fur and black stripes
TIRED: Feeling like you need to rest or sleep
TOASTER: An appliance that makes bread crispy and brown
TOILET: A bowl used for getting rid of body waste
TOMATO: A soft red fruit often used as a vegetable
TORTOISE: A slow animal with a hard shell that lives on land
TOWEL: A piece of cloth used for drying yourself or things
TOWER: A very tall building or structure
TOWN: A place with many buildings that is smaller than a city
TRACTOR: A powerful farm vehicle with large tires
TRAFFIC: Many cars and trucks moving along a road together
TRAIN: A long vehicle that travels along railway tracks
TRAVEL: Going from one place to another far away
TREASURE: Valuable things like gold and jewels hidden away
TREE: A tall plant with a trunk and leaves
TRIANGLE: A shape with three sides and three corners
TROLL: A grumpy creature that lives under bridges
TRUCK: A large strong vehicle used for carrying goods
TUNNEL: A path built under the ground or a mountain
TURKEY: A large farm bird often eaten at holidays
TURTLE: A reptile with a shell that lives in the ocean
UMBRELLA: A folding cover used for keeping dry in the rain
UNICORN: A horse with a single horn on its head
VACATION: A long holiday spent away from home
VACUUM: A machine used for sucking up dirt from the floor
VALLEY: An area of low land between hills or mountains
VAMPIRE: A spooky person who sleeps in a coffin
VAN: A vehicle used for carrying people or things
VICTORY: Winning a game or a great battle
VILLAGE: A small group of houses in the countryside
VULTURE: A large bird that eats dead animals
WALK: To move on your feet at a normal pace
WALL: The solid structure that makes the sides of a room
WALLET: A small flat case used for carrying money and cards
WALRUS: A massive sea animal with long ivory tusks
WASP: A flying insect that is yellow and black and can sting
WATCH: A small clock worn on the wrist to tell the time
WATER: A clear liquid we need to drink to live
WEBSITE: A place on the internet with info and games
WHALE: A massive mammal that lives under the sea
WHEEL: A round object that turns to make a vehicle move
WIND: Moving air you can feel but not see
WINDOW: An opening in a wall with glass to see through
WINDY: When there is a lot of wind blowing around
WINTER: The cold time when it might snow outside
WITCH: A woman with magical powers in stories
WIZARD: A man with magical powers in stories
WOLF: A wild animal that looks like a dog and howls
WOMBAT: A sturdy Australian animal that digs tunnels
WOODPECKER: A bird that taps on tree trunks with its beak
WORD: A set of letters that has a meaning together
YACHT: A large expensive boat used for pleasure trips
YOGURT: A creamy food made from fermented milk
ZEBRA: A wild horse from Africa with black and white stripes
ZIPPER: A metal or plastic fastener used for closing clothes
ZOMBIE: A person who has come back to life in stories
